Question_1.Context: In thermoelectric materials, the figure of merit ZT is a dimensionless value that quantifies the efficiency of a material's thermoelectric conversion. It is defined by the formula ZT = α2σT/κ, where α is the thermopower, σ is the electrical conductivity, and κ is the thermal conductivity.
Question_1.Question: What does the figure of merit ZT in thermoelectric materials represent?
Question_1.A: The electrical resistance of the material
Question_1.B: The efficiency of a material's thermoelectric conversion
Question_1.C: The thermal resistance of the material
Question_1.D: The mechanical strength of the material
Question_1.Source: The quality of the thermoelectric materials used to make them. This quality is quantified by a dimensionless figure of merit ZT = α2σT/κ, with thermal conductivity κ, electrical conductivity σ, and thermopower α.

Question_2.Context: Thermoelectric materials can be enhanced by reducing lattice contributions to thermal conductivity, which can be achieved by introducing nanostructures that scatter phonons.
Question_2.Question: How can the thermoelectric performance of materials be improved according to recent research?
Question_2.A: By increasing the lattice contributions to thermal conductivity
Question_2.C: By introducing nanostructures to scatter phonons
Question_2.D: By increasing the size of the material's crystals
Question_2.Source: Research in tetradymites has focused on reducing the lattice contributions to thermal conductivity by introducing nanostructures. Nanocomposites based on tetradymite alloys result in large ZT improvements, which is credited to phonon scattering.

Question_3.Context: Effective medium theory suggests that in a composite material, the thermoelectric figure of merit cannot exceed the greatest value of any single constituent unless the constituents interact with each other.
Question_3.Question: What does the effective medium theory state about the thermoelectric figure of merit in composite materials?
Question_3.A: It can exceed the value of any single constituent if the constituents are metallic
Question_3.B: It is always lower than the value of any single constituent
Question_3.C: It cannot exceed the value of any single constituent unless the constituents interact
Question_3.D: It is independent of the constituents' properties
Question_3.Source: The effective medium theory, which states that the ZT in a composite material cannot exceed the greatest value of any single constituent, if the constituents do not interact.

Question_4.Context: In thermoelectric materials, doping refers to the introduction of impurities into a semiconductor to change its electrical properties. Local doping around an insulating inclusion can reduce thermal conductivity without equivalently increasing electrical resistivity.
Question_4.Question: What is the effect of local doping around an insulating inclusion in thermoelectric materials?
Question_4.A: It increases both thermal and electrical conductivity
Question_4.B: It reduces thermal conductivity without an equivalent increase in electrical resistivity
Question_4.C: It decreases the thermopower of the material
Question_4.D: It has no effect on the material's properties
Question_4.Source: The reduction in thermal conductivity absent an equivalent reduction in electrical conductivity results from local doping of the matrix around an inserted phase (here, beads).

Question_6.Context: Thermoelectric coolers operate on the Peltier effect and have several advantages, such as no regular maintenance and no vibration, but their efficiency is competitive only in low-power applications.
Question_6.Question: What is a limitation of thermoelectric coolers that operate on the Peltier effect?
Question_6.C: Their efficiency is competitive only in low-power applications
Question_6.D: They emit large amounts of greenhouse gases

Question_7.Context: Thermoelectric materials are often made of tetradymite materials, which are alloys that crystallize in the 3m crystallographic point group and have been used to create conventional Peltier modules.
Question_7.Question: What type of materials are conventional Peltier modules typically made of?
Question_7.Source: Conventional Peltier modules are made of tetradymite [2] materials (alloys of general formula (Bi,Sb)2(Te,Se)3 that crystallize in the 3m crystallographic point group)

Question_8.Context: In the context of thermoelectric materials, the term 'aliovalent' refers to an impurity that has a different valence than the host material, which can be used to dope the material and alter its electrical properties.
Question_8.Question: What does the term 'aliovalent' signify in the context of doping thermoelectric materials?
Question_8.A: An impurity with the same valence as the host material
Question_8.B: An impurity that does not change the electrical properties
Question_8.C: An impurity with a different valence than the host material
Question_8.D: A pure element that enhances thermal conductivity
Question_8.Source: An electrically and thermally insulating medium is distributed into a conventional thermoelectric host material but is coated with an aliovalent acceptor that is allowed to diffuse locally into the host matrix, thereby doping it locally.

Question_9.Context: The thermal conductivity of a thermoelectric material can be decreased by adding insulating inclusions, which can lead to an improvement in the figure of merit ZT.
Question_9.Question: What is the effect of adding insulating inclusions to a thermoelectric material?
Question_9.Source: The thermal conductivity decreases when the insulating material is added, but the more electrically conducting region around the insulator prevents an equally large increase in electrical resistivity.

Question_10.Context: In thermoelectric materials, the power factor is defined as the product of the square of the thermopower (α) and the electrical conductivity (σ).
Question_10.Question: What is the power factor in the context of thermoelectric materials?
Question_10.A: The ratio of thermal conductivity to electrical conductivity
Question_10.B: The product of the square of the thermopower and the electrical conductivity
Question_10.C: The difference between thermal conductivity and electrical resistivity
Question_10.D: The sum of the thermopower and the electrical resistivity
Question_10.Source: The power factor α2σ can be enhanced, an accompanying increase in thermal conductivity will always limit the figure of merit.
